s.text: The Forgive and Forget strategy has this virtue for Republicans: It is the only way they're going to win a clean PR victory.
This does not a winning issue make.
The sound of young conservatives baying for DNA has subsided.

The only poll that I've heard about that makes any sense, which may be the one the GOP is reading, is the ABC News survey (I think) saying that 69 percent of Americans would clear Clinton if he makes a clean breast of it.

As Flytrap II enters Week II, it is segueing gracefully into the second stage of scandal: The initial glee of Clinton's enemies has matured into thoughtful magnanimity.
As Flytrap II enters Week II, it is segueing gracefully into the second stage of scandal: The initial glee of Clinton's enemies has matured into thoughtful magnanimity.

Whether they've reached their conclusion for cynical or idealistic reasons, Hatch and Co. do seem to have hit on the only solution to this mess, the only outcome that will punish Clinton adequately, satisfy his persecutors enough to quiet them, and save us from two more years of this horror.
If last week's theme was high dudgeon, this week's will be high-mindedness.
The Republicans' new strategy seems to be: (Possibly) Forgive and (Maybe) Forget.
Forgive and Forget?
Even if Republicans decide later that they don't actually forgive and forget, it may be too late.
There is no sign yet that the administration is tempted by mea culpa/ Forgive and Forget.
Forgive and Forget?
